objectPrototype.name: objectPrototype
objectPrototype.description:
Extend Object.prototype with helper methods to simplify inheritance

Escape uses prototypal style inheritance rather than the constructor / pseudo-classical 
approach used by many javascript developers. The "blueprints" for each type of object
are defined as objects in files named "<type>Prototype.js". A new object of that type can 
be created using "var newObj = <type>Prototype.create();". To create a new prototype based
upon a previous one use "var newPrototype = <type>Prototype.extend();"

It could be argued that extending Object.prototype in this way is an anti-pattern due to the
effect it could have on code written by those who are unaware that it has been extended. However,
the code below takes account of the most common types of conflict and employs suitable preventative
measures so this sort of problem should not occur.

palette.name: palette
palette.description: Command palette for the game editor

playerPrototype.description:

For more information on how Escape uses inheritance see objectPrototype.js

For more information on how Escape uses inheritance see objectPrototype.js

If you're looking for something and can't find it then try the map module

timer.name: timer
timer.description:

TODO: expand with functionality to set custom timers

util.name: util
util.description: Utility methods that do not really belong any where else

vector.name: vector
vector.description:
A library of useful vector math functions

At first glance it may appear that a nicer syntax could be obtained by creating a vector type
and attaching these methods to the prototype. However, the most common use case is an object
of a different type that happens to have x and y properties. As using apply/call is fiddly
in terms of syntax and multiple inheritance is memory inefficient in javascript (an object can 
only be linked to a single prototype), I believe this approach to be best.

The baddy searches for the target by heading off in the direction the target

classitems.description: The baddy returns to its start location. It then enters watch mode

classitems.description: The baddy goes to its current waypoint, then reverts to its original orders

classitems.name: process

classitems.description:
Takes a string and returns the value of the global variable with that name

To avoid global cluttering this method understands '.' syntax to follow the namespace/object chain
The only usage envisaged so far is the loading of variable names from JSON. Any other usage probably means 
we're doing something wrong. Even the json example may mean that but I've not yet thought of a better way!
classitems.name: valFromString

classitems.description: Moves an array element from one index to another

params.name: arr
params.description: The array to modify

params.name: currentIndex
params.description: The index the element currently occupies

params.name: newIndex
params.description: The new index for the element to occupy

classitems.description:
returns a vector with integer values for both x and y coordinates

This is particularly useful when rendering to the canvas where there is a big performance hit for non-integer values
classitems.name: round

params.name: v
params.description: The vector to be rounded

classitems.description: Adds two vectors together, returning the resulting vector
classitems.name: add

params.name: v1
params.description: A vector

params.name: v2
params.description: A vector

classitems.description: Returns a new vector that is a copy of the inital vector
classitems.name: clone

classitems.description: Subtracts one vector from another
classitems.name: subtract

params.name: v1
params.description: The vector to subtract

params.name: v2
params.description: The vector to subtract from

classitems.description: Returns a vector of the same magnitude pointing in the opposite direction
classitems.name: reverse

params.name: v
params.description: The initial vector

classitems.description: Calculates the magnitude (length) of a vector
classitems.name: mag

params.name: v
params.description: The vector

classitems.description: Calculates the distance between two vectors (imagine they represent points)
classitems.name: distance

params.name: v1
params.description: The first vector

params.name: v2
params.description: The second vector

return.description: The distance between the two vectors

classitems.description: Returns a new vector pointing the same direction but with length 1
classitems.name: normalise

params.name: v
params.description: The vector to normalise

classitems.description: Returns a new vector pointing in the same direction but of the specified length
classitems.name: setLength

params.name: v
params.description: The intial vector

params.name: length
params.description: The new length

classitems.description:
Calculates the dot product between two vectors

This can be thought of as a number indicating how closely the two vectors are aligned
classitems.name: dot

params.name: v1
params.description: The first vector

params.name: v2
params.description: The second vector

classitems.description: The angle between two vectors (in radians)
classitems.name: angle

params.name: v1
params.description: The first vector

params.name: v2
params.description: The second vector

params.name: dirMatters
params.description: If true then the angle is +ve for clockwise angles, -ve for anticlockwise. If false the angle is always positive

classitems.description: Converts an angle (in radians) to a normaLised vector
classitems.name: angleToVector

params.name: angle
params.description: The angle (directional and in radians) to convert
